column4: for CIFS, there is a _netdev option to check if the net file system is up or not.
I am not sure of NFS has that option or not.
Hmm, an option for what. Does it go in /etc/fstab, or somewhere else?
should work fine under fstab.
just check if that option exists for NFS or not.
But if it is in fstab, how would X know not to start? My problem is not that home does not get mounted, but that it is not mounted at the time I log in.
then create a session under gnome and manually mount the folder again?
create a auto run session for gnome and let it run when you login
working?

I would rather have the init-script (which does the mount) wait until the mount is done, before starting X. I have been running Gentoo for years, and recently switched to Ubuntu on my desktop. Never had this problem before.
that's what I talked about. See if there is an option for networking delay like _netdev (network device), and you are good to go
Ahh, OK. I didn't realize that was what would happen from putting it in /etc/fstab. Thanks, I will check it out.
good luck
http://linux.die.net/man/5/nfs  maybe the timeout parameter will work. I guess.
I found /etc/inid.d/mountnfs.sh, which seems to do what I want, but perhaps I need to move gdm from S30 to some later point.
good point.
Will try to reboot and see if it works. Thanks so far!

Hmm. That didn't work. I tried putting mountnfs.sh at S29. It appears that _netdev is valid for nfs, but AFAICT it delays mounting the nfs until after the network is configured, not delaying the script until the mount is done.
you said you'd delay gdm script.
or change time out parameter for NFS?
Yeah, and I thought that would be done by putting mountnfs.sh at S29 and leaving gdm at S30. The whole idea of mountnfs.sh should be to delay the startup process until the devices are mounted.
or it will be just easier that you create a session under gnome, and let it remount the NFS when starting gnome. It'll be easier
